Evaluation_Questions: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken
What is your overall assessment of this course
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor
The primary instructor's provided students with helpful and timely feedback
The instructor established a positive learning environment
The instructor raised questions or problems that encouraged me to think critically
Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved
Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not
Comments_List: 5hours
5 hour
10-15 hours
10+ on heavier weeks, and 5-7 normal
Depended on the week! Some weeks 5, others 15-20 when big assignments were due!
About 3-4 on average
If coursework was evenly completed across the group then I would spend about 3 hours a week on assignments/readings. However, if group work was disproportionate then about 4-5 hours.
10-15 hours per week
10 hours
5-10, on average
Amazing course, no complaints at al.

I really enjoyed this course. I felt that the structure and organization of the course was perfect. The assignments were very clear and scheduled throughout the semester. The workload definitely built up towards the end of the semester but I felt that it wasn't too much. I also enjoyed the end of the semester presentations where we could see the preliminary results of many of the projects we had heard about all semester.

The course is a good and thorough introduction to qualitative methods. I think it would have been really helpful for our learning and processing of the methodology if had more peer-review and discussion, especially for individual output 1.

This is hands down the most brilliant course I've taken at YSPH, and one of the best courses I've taken in my academic career. It's perfectly structured to the layout of the academic semester, providing ample opportunity during class time to work on group projects so you're not spending time outside of class coordinating schedules and scrambling to get things done. Breaking up assignments week-by-week was great. Expectations never felt unmanageable.  

More importantly all of the tangible skills I've learned are incredibly applicable to my future work. Moving forward I feel incredibly confident in my ability to design a qualitative research study and write a paper suitable for publishing.

Honestly zero weaknesses. I loved this class.
Liked the class time to work on projects in groups

I thought this was an excellent introduction to qualitative skills (coding, interviewing, etc.). Dr. Keene was a passionate, expert lecturer. This course is work heavy - our final report was 50+ pages, and our individual assignments mid-year (with coded interviews, memos, etc.) were over 50+ pages as well. But Dr. Keene and the TFs responding in a timely and helpful manner to our assignments they were also present in class/after class to help address our concerns. The course is well structured, but has a lot of little assignments that are due every week (this might not be appealing to some students). Furthermore, the class has individual assignments that are due frequently, and although the dates are clearly marked when things were due, the volume of material due might put some students off/confuse them. It certainly keeps you on your toes. The opportunity to interview community members (and get IRB approval, like our group did, for possible future publication), was INCREDIBLE and really leads you step by step through the qualitative process (from designing surveys, creating methodology, getting IRB approval, interviewing, etc.). In this way, this class provided a practicum-like experience to gain an in depth introduction to qualitative methods. Danya's lectures were interesting, relevant, and conversational  I would highly recommend this course and this instructor.
I think that this is an incredible course. Danya is amazing. It was a little stressful to get all of the interviews done on time, but I learned so much from this calss.

I loved this course in terms of content and the skills gained- in fact, I'm already implementing a lot of the skills either in other courses or in outside research and it's been so helpful! I thought that the material was super engaging and the practical application of what we were learning really cemented the concepts. I also really enjoyed towards the end of the course when we were introduced to guest speakers in other fields of qualitative research. The downfall of the course would be the lack of accountability in the team-based assignments (group outputs, presentation, final report). Nearly the entirety of work fell onto a couple people while others literally just did not care. This was frustrating and continued despite attempts internally to try and increase accountability.

As someone more interested in the quantitative aspect of public health, I was a bit wary of the course. However, this class gave me a new appreciation for qualitative research and I had a lot of fun with the semester project. I think I learned the most from this course than any other course I have taken this semester. I feel like the skills I learned from this course can be transferred to public health practice.

Strengths: gives good overview on qualitative methods, provides several examples of what is expected of students

Weakness: none really, I think this course meets its goals

The courses professor is a great instructor, and clearly cares a lot about her students and teaching. However, the material/substance of the course is extremely elementary, and there is a lot of unnecessary and time-consuming busy work. The course should not be listed as a requirement for doctoral students.

This was the BEST course I have taken at YSPH. I have gained tangible skills and am proud that our group was able to complete such a quality qualitative project over the course of the semester. I would recommend this course to any student and will take the skills with me into my future career.
Very good. I learned a lot and it is very applicable to the real world. It was good to learn from fellow students.
Individual assessment 2 could have been assigned earlier so we could focus more on our group paper near the end of the semester.
I really enjoyed the qualitative project and I have learned a lot!

Strengths: Very practical and thorough.
Weaknesses: I don't think people should use this in conjunction with other projects (i.e. dissertations) because their work may end up taking a different shape.
I thought it was an amazing course that laid the foundation for qualitative research. I really saw no weaknesses in the course.
The instructor and content of this course were excellent.

Strengths: Great material that inspired new projects and directions relevant for my research. Honed previously learned skills. I wish more time was spent on the data analysis. Although I understand this is only an intro course, the hardest past is the data analysis and too little time is spent there. 

Weaknesses: Too broad. Only superficially cover each methodology. An advanced version or a year long course would be great for individuals looking to use this professionally as well as PhD students. 

Other weaknesses of the course load: the final 2-3 weeks of the course had too many assignments back-to-back. The article criticism seemed like extra work that was not very informative to my learning experience. I would have prefer for this to be optional (for extra credit) or assigned the month prior when work load was less. Between finishing up a presentation, data analysis and writing a paper, students are super overwhelmed at the end of the semester.

Overall, I really enjoyed this course. I felt the pacing was adequate, especially considering the scale of most of the group projects and the limited time period in which to conduct everything. The concepts taught in class and discussed by guest speakers were interesting and discussions were engaging. The class really made good use of the time available.

Strengths:
-interesting and engaging subject matter and topics; really enjoyed the discussions about quantitative, qualitative, and mixed methods work and enjoyed discussing the methods of current well-known ethnographic and semi-qualitative works such as 'On the Run' and 'Evicted'
-all the projects were fascinating and it was great to hear about the findings and culmination of everyone's projects, and to hear that many, if not all, of them are intending to take those projects further, it really helped to round out the course and show the ongoing nature of qualitative study 
-the instructor and TFs were great and very helpful and supportive; their feedback was timely and really helped our group's project along
-the examples of outputs and final assignments were great and really helpful  
-setting aside time for group meetings at the end of class on Thursday was really appreciated

Weaknesses:
-doing more small group discussions may help to encourage more input and discussion from all students; I enjoyed the small group discussions when they did occur and I think it really helps to hear different voices and perspectives, which are not always heard during whole class discussions

This course is fantastic. It does not have any weaknesses, in my opinion. I feel very strong about constructing a qualitative research project from beginning to end. The preliminary research question development to analytical skills gained in this experience were incredible. This class was intensive, but well worth it.

This course is a fantastic, in-depth immersion into designing and conducting high quality qualitative research. Theory and readings were paired expertly with assignments. Assignments also made a lot of chronological sense, and all contributed to the final project, which was great. The instructor and TFs supplied in-depth feedback on each assignment, and there was always opportunity to re-work. This class was comprehensive and I can't think of a single way that it could be improved.
This course was excellent. Well laid out and everything flowed well

Qualitative Research Methods is the best course I took in my first year at YSPH. This course is tough and time-consuming, but I came away with solid skills in qualitative methods and a sound understanding of the theory behind qualitative research. The classroom environment fostered great discussion and Danya is an engaging and incredibly knowledgable instructor! I do think the course could benefit from a restructuring of assignment due dates. For instance, I wonder if final presentations could be during finals week to spread out the last few group outputs and give us more time for analysis, group discussion, etc. -- but that could be a very personal preference.
Amazing course, really well designed. Would love for an advanced qualitative methods course

Overall, this course was fantastic! It provided us with an opportunity to complete a mini research project that applied the skills we were learning about qualitative analysis. 

Strengths: numerous examples via readings and past students' works, interesting and non-clear cut discussions of ethics regarding qualitative projects, engagement with other teams' projects which provided increased moral support ( something I feel YSPH needs more of!), the involvment of students outside of YSPH (allowed us to have more interprofessional interactions)

Weaknesses: .... can't think of any!
She is the best!

Danya was an amazing professor. This was must first introduction to qualitative research and I'm so glad Danya was the one who taught me this skill. She is a great, energetic, enthusiastic teacher and a great researcher. I appreciated how much she cared about teaching this course, her passion really shined through. She is very inspiring and despite being a quantitative researcher, I loved being in this class.
Danya is amazing and understanding.

Brilliant! The most supportive, encouraging, and conscientious professor I've at YSPH. I appreciate the thoughtfulness provided with all feedback on coursework. I often feel this sort of feedback is lacking in this program and Danya's approach was a welcome change of pace.
Wonderful

Excellent. Very passionate, accessible lecturer who made herself highly available to students in class and out. Her comments were incredibly helpful when designing and carrying out our research project.

Professor Keene is an absolutely amazing professor! She is brilliant in what she does and always willing to talk through ideas and concepts to get you where you need to be. I wish I could take another class with her.
I think she did a great job prioritizing the different topics of the course.
Danya was great. She provided guidance whenever we needed and gave detailed feedback on all of our assignments to further our project progress

Dr. Keene is a gem of YSPH! She brings so much compassion and encouragement to what could otherwise be an intimidating methodological course. She provides thorough and very (!) prompt feedback on every assignment. I was so grateful to be able to learn from her.
Danya is amazing-so smart, talented, and encouraging.
Prof is great :)
Dr. Keene is a great instructor, I really enjoyed her class!

Strengths: Very communicative, helpful, and supportive
Weaknesses: Cannot think of any
Danya is amazing! So charming and personable. She provided excellent feedback and made research so much fun.

Danya provided timely and useful feedback and made herself available to students. It was clear from the quality of the course that she is knowledgable about the subject matter and well-prepared for class.

Excellent professor. Established great rapport and trust with students. I felt like my comments were always considered. The professor is very thoughtful. I enjoyed being in this class. Lectures were engaging and always dynamic, huge plus!

Danya is an amazing instructor and I am happy I got to learn from her this year. She was really supportive and encouraging throughout the semester and throughout this process. I felt she really tried to address student concerns and questions and she provided a great introduction to qualitative methods.

Danya did a great job. She was an inspiring, knowledgeable professor. By sharing her own grant critiques, I feel better prepared to defend qualitative research in an academic setting. As well, she allowed us to think a lot about different issues and dive into the qualitative methods. Danya is one of the best professors I have had the pleasure of working with.

This professor is phenomenal; truly one of the best that I have had in my time at YSPH. Clearly an expert in the field of qualitative research who is passionate about sharing her love for her craft with her students. I felt lucky to take this class and learn from her expertise. This professor is passionate and compassionate, and really cares about her students. I cannot say enough good things about her.
Dr. Keene is an amazing instructor, very encouraging and gives clear instructions and critiques

Danya is incredible! She is so knowledgable, fosters engaging classroom discussion, and truly invites everyone's perspectives and opinions. She's clearly refined this course over the year to make it run so seamlessly. I also appreciated her flexibility on due dates given various groups' challenges with recruitment.
Danya is a phenomenal instructor.

Dr. Keene did an outstanding job in teaching this course! She was constantly present for her students, able to stick well to the dates she gave us on returning assignments, and gave extremely beneficial feedback through every aspect of the semester.
This course would be useful for literally anyone.

This class is a great way to learn the foundations of qualitative research. It is a well structured and organized course that definitely requires significant work. You learn a lot and get hands on experience conducing a qualitative study. I would recommend this course to anyone who wants to learn about qualitative research methods and who has the time to put the effort in.

100% take this class regardless of whether or not you are required to. YSPH doesn't have enough coursework in qualitative or mixed methods research -- this is basically your only opportunity to learn and develop your skill set in these areas. What you learn is highly transferable to the "real world" and/or academic research, so regardless of your future path, everything taught is valuable. I absolutely loved this class and can't speak highly enough of it and Danya's teaching methods. Once more (with feeling): take this class!!
Would recommend to another student

Introduction to qualitative methods course that allows students to learn the foundations of qualitative research (from choosing an appropriate methodology, to survey design, writing qualitative papers, assessing qualitative studies for strengths and weaknesses, interviewing, and submitting an IRB). It was certainly a heavy work load, but very rewarding.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student. It may be a lot of work but it's worth it!
Great way to build qualitative research skills. It's especially helpful if you'll be doing interviews for internships or projects following the course

I would definitely recommend the course to other students. Qualitative research is so important for any area of public health and I think more people outside of SBS should really consider taking it. The course is labor intensive but it is satisfying to see a project come to fruition and hopefully positively impact some people or an organization.

Good introduction to qualitative methods by hands-on experience interviewing and coding for analysis.
Would recommend to other students interested in conducting own research in qual. methods
Love it, everyone should take it.

A class on qualitative research methods.
Yes, I would highly recommend it.
Perfect course to understand the foundation of qualitative research.
I would recommend this course to a fellow student. It is one of the most useful I have taken during my MPH.

The course provides a thorough introduction to qualitative research and all the methodologies available in the field. Highly recommend this course to anyone thinking about incorporating this type of research into their work.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student, especially if they are interested in qualitative research methods. This course is also useful even to just understand what qualitative methods are, particularly in relation to quantitative research methods. Students will most likely encounter qualitative research while at Yale and in the future, so I feel getting a foundational knowledge of the purpose and application of qualitative methods (and mixed methods) is useful for any public health student. However, I would caution students about the workload, as it is heavier than most other courses and requires a significant amount of time and dedication.

This class is fantastic and any person that desires to understand more about qualitative research should take this course. Danya is a great professor that creates a team environment. The class allows you to work closely with a group of students on a project that inspires you. The research project is yours from the first step to the last. By applying qualitative methods and logic, one conducts a mini-project and is able to feel successful in this semester.

This course is an in-depth introduction to qualitative research that really teaches by doing in the sense that you must complete almost all aspects of qualitative research that you learn about during the course of this class. What you learn about qualitative research, interviews, focus groups, and more can be used for other classes and when conducting research of your own. You will gain many useful skills by taking this class. I completely and unequivocally recommend this class to every student at Yale. If I could take this class again and do another qualitative project I would. I have already recommended it to friends interested in qualitative work.
Take it, it was fun and very helpful to learning Qualitative skills

If you are at all interested in qualitative methods, take this course! Even if you are not interested, take this course and you'll still gain rich knowledge and wisdom. You'll learn solid practical skills, the theory underpinning qualitative research, and will get to complete a qualitative project from start to finish.
Absolutely would recommend.

This course allows students to better understand how to utilize qualitative study designs through a tangible, hand-on method. It goes beyond just working in on a group project as it allows students to pour themselves into a project and create connections with others on a project that they truly care about. The course ensures that students are close to their projects and their participants as well as the narrative of their participants. I recommend it to every student who wishes to do studies with human subjects as qualitative data is vastly underutilized and is one of the only mechanisms to deeply understand a patient's perspective. Further, students should not miss out on the opportunity to work under Dr. Keene, who is a champion for her students.
